item.title: China accused of cyber-attack on Microsoft Exchange servers
item.description: The UK, US and EU have accused China of carrying out an attack on Microsoft Exchange email servers.

item.title: Global shares slide amid Covid economic recovery fears
item.description: Stock markets in the UK, the US and Europe fall on concerns that rising cases may impede a recovery.

item.title: Horse racing: Thousands of racehorses killed in slaughterhouses
item.description: Some horses once trained by some of racing’s top names are being slaughtered, BBC Panorama finds.

item.title: NYPD officer uses crisp packet to save stabbing victim
item.description: The police officer in New York has been praised for his decisive actions.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Composer Keigo Oyamada resigns over bullying at school
item.description: Keigo Oyamada resigned after it came out that he bullied disabled classmates and boasted about it.

item.title: Katie Hopkins deported from Australia over quarantine rules
item.description: Katie Hopkins - a far-right British commentator - bragged about plans to break isolation rules.

item.title: Pegasus: Spyware sold to governments 'targets activists'
item.description: Israeli tech firm NSO denies media reports that its software has been sold to authoritarian regimes.

item.title: Carlos Ghosn: Father and son sentenced for helping ex-Nissan boss escape
item.description: Michael and Peter Taylor were convicted of helping ex-Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn escape Japan in 2019.

item.title: 19 July: England Covid restrictions ease as PM urges caution
item.description: There is no limit on how many people can meet, nightclubs can reopen and large events can resume.

item.title: Mumbai rains: At least 30 killed in downpour
item.description: Heavy monsoon rains have been lashing Mumbai, India’s financial capital.

item.title: US Olympic gymnast tests positive for Covid
item.description: A female USA gymnast tests positive for Covid-19 and another team member is identified as a close contact.

item.title: Kurt Westergaard, Danish cartoonist behind Muhammad cartoon, dies at 86
item.description: His 2005 drawing of the Prophet Muhammad sparked protests across the Muslim world.

item.title: Kris Wu: Brands drop China star over teen sex allegations
item.description: Singer-actor Kris Wu has denied the accusations and said he was filing a defamation suit.

item.title: Guto Harri quits GB News over taking the knee row
item.description: The journalist was suspended for a gesture made during a chat about the abuse of black footballers.

item.title: Lex Gillette: Record-breaking blind long jumper
item.description: With the support of his sighted guide, the four-time Paralympic medallist hopes to win gold in Tokyo.

item.title: England nightclubs reopen: Cheers and celebrations as clubbers return for first night out
item.description: For some revellers in Leeds, this was the first time they'd ever been to a nightclub.

item.title: Athletes test positive for Covid at Olympic village
item.description: Two South Africa footballers test positive for Covid-19 in the Olympic village, while eight Team GB athletes and staff are cleared to resume training.

item.title: Moment mum saves boy, 5, from kidnap attempt
item.description: The mother pulled her son from a car after he was taken from her in broad daylight in the New York City.

item.title: India farmers' protest: Living on a highway in protest
item.description: Seven months on, farmers are still striking against contentious new laws outside the national capital.

item.title: Hubble space telescope's function is restored
item.description: Engineers restore the Hubble Space Telescope to full operations, after a computer glitch in June.

item.title: ICYMI: Dead flamingos and a floating solar farm
item.description: Here are some stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Covid-19 tests while you wait in Israeli airport
item.description: Ben Gurion airport in Israel has introduced fast Covid-19 tests for travellers.

item.title: Joshi is swapping life in captivity for a new start in the jungle
item.description: After a lifetime in captivity, Joshi is going to live in the jungle in Congo-Brazzaville.

item.title: Latin American Foto Festival: Strength and resistance
item.description: Caribbean and Latin American photography features in the fourth Annual Latin American Foto Festival.

item.title: Your pictures on the theme of 'under the stars'
item.description: A selection of striking images from our readers around the world.

item.title: Elizabeth Gaskell: The Victorian author feeling the Bridgerton effect
item.description: Experts say the success of period dramas online has brought Elizabeth Gaskell a new audience.

item.title: Olympics: Defying threats, Iranian athletes speak out to back ban
item.description: Olympics organisers are being urged to investigate allegations of threats, discrimination and abuse.

item.title: Covid: Is China's vaccine success waning in Asia?
item.description: Thailand and Indonesia's switch to other Covid jabs has raised questions about Chinese vaccines.

item.title: Nigeria's security crises - five different threats
item.description: Almost every part of Nigeria is facing a security crisis - from kidnapping to extremist insurgencies.

item.title: How to cool your home in a warming world
item.description: Low-energy designs and technologies can keep homes comfortable, come rain or shine.

item.title: Using plastic waste to help solve sand shortages
item.description: With construction sand in short supply crushed plastic is being used as an alternative.

item.title: The Broadway dancer whose lockdown business bloomed
item.description: When Covid closed New York theatres, dancer Robbie Fairchild started a business that put down roots.

item.title: Why was my tweet about football labelled abusive?
item.description: A BBC journalist sets out to discover how Twitter moderates posts after he was banned from the platform.

item.title: Germany floods: Where are the worst-hit areas?
item.description: Maps, images and graphics showing the heavy rainfall and flooding that has caused widespread damage.

item.title: Abir Moussi: The Tunisian MP who was slapped but not beaten
item.description: Abir Moussi uses a megaphone in parliament and gets death threats but many say her voice is crucial.

item.title: Under the skin of OnlyFans
item.description: A BBC investigation reveals concerns about how the site, known for porn, is structured and moderated.

item.title: Hamilton racially abused online after British Grand Prix victory
item.description: Lewis Hamilton is the target of racist abuse on social media after his victory in Sunday's British Grand Prix.

item.title: England beat Pakistan by 45 runs to set up T20 series decider
item.description: England's spinners squeeze Pakistan to claim an emphatic 45-run victory in the second Twenty20 and level the series at 1-1.

item.title: 'Disgraceful scenes must never be repeated' - FA announces review into Wembley security breaches
item.description: The Football Association says it is determined to ensure the "disgraceful scenes" that marred the Euro 2020 final at Wembley are "never able to be repeated".

item.title: Cavendish feels he is 'getting younger' after cementing status as Tour great
item.description: How Mark Cavendish rode into Tour de France history to share the stage win record with Eddy Merckx and to win the green jersey.

item.title: Rangers to face Malmo or HJK Helsinki in Champions League qualifying
item.description: Rangers will face Malmo or HJK Helsinki in the Champions League third qualifying round while Celtic and St Johnstone are drawn to face PSV or Galatasaray.

item.title: The Open 2021: Collin Morikawa says Royal St George's victory 'hard to grasp'
item.description: American Collin Morikawa says he "wants more" after winning The Open to claim his second major title by the age of 24.

item.title: Esther Dingley: Partner vows to keep searching for missing hiker
item.description: The partner of missing hiker Esther Dingley explains why he won't give up searching for her.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Unvaccinated patients with many regrets
item.description: The number of Covid patients in Bradford Royal Infirmary is rising sharply - and half are unvaccinated.

item.title: Olympic Games: 'Gang life nearly killed me - sprinting was my way out'
item.description: As Darren Campbell emerged as a talented teenage sprinter, he was leading a double life as a gang member. A twist of fate broke him free.

item.title: 'Indians don't talk about sex - so I help them'
item.description: An Indian sex coach says parents turn to her for advice as sex education is not available in schools.

item.title: Ghana's Kojo Marfo: Sell-out show for butcher-turned-painter
item.description: He's got rock star fans and two sold-out shows to his name, but Kojo Marfo prefers life's simple joys.
